t: Job 13
Lo,*p mine eye hath seen all this, mine ear hath heard and understood it.
What*p ye know, the same do I know also: I am not inferior unto you.
Surely*p I would speak to the Almighty, and I desire to reason with God.
But*p ye are forgers of lies, ye are all physicians of no value.
O*p that ye would altogether hold your peace! and it should be your wisdom.
Hear*p now my reasoning, and hearken to the pleadings of my lips.
Will*p ye speak wickedly for God? and talk deceitfully for him?
Will*p ye accept his person? will ye contend for God?
Is*p it good that he should search you out? or as one man mocketh another, do ye so mock him?
He*p will surely reprove you, if ye do secretly accept persons.
Shall*p not his excellency make you afraid? and his dread fall upon you?
Your*p remembrances are like unto ashes, your bodies to bodies of clay.
Hold*p your peace, let me alone, that I may speak, and let come on me what will.
Wherefore*p do I take my flesh in my teeth, and put my life in mine hand?
Though*p he slay me, yet will I trust in him: but I will maintain mine own ways before him.
He*p also shall be my salvation: for an hypocrite shall not come before him.
Hear*p diligently my speech, and my declaration with your ears.
Behold*p now, I have ordered my cause; I know that I shall be justified.
Who*p is he that will plead with me? for now, if I hold my tongue, I shall give up the ghost.
Only*p do not two things unto me: then will I not hide myself from thee.
Withdraw*p thine hand far from me: and let not thy dread make me afraid.
Then*p call thou, and I will answer: or let me speak, and answer thou me.
How*p many are mine iniquities and sins? make me to know my transgression and my sin.
Wherefore*p hidest thou thy face, and holdest me for thine enemy?
Wilt*p thou break a leaf driven to and fro? and wilt thou pursue the dry stubble?
For*p thou writest bitter things against me, and makest me to possess the iniquities of my youth.
Thou*p puttest my feet also in the stocks, and lookest narrowly unto all my paths; thou settest a print upon the heels of my feet.
And*p he, as a rotten thing, consumeth, as a garment that is moth eaten.
